277    # Get the variables only
278    def get_measurements(self, station, startDate=None, endDate=None, variables=None, dataset='controlled', aggregate=False, quality_flags=False):
279            """
280                Get measurements from a station.
281
282                Parameters:
283                -----------
284                - station (str): The station ID.
285                - startDate (str, optional): The start date of the measurement period in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
286                - endDate (str, optional): The end date of the measurement period in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
287                - variables (list, optional): The variables to retrieve measurements for. If None, all variables are retrieved.
288                - dataset (str, optional): The dataset to retrieve measurements from. Default is 'controlled'.
289                - aggregate (bool, optional): Whether to aggregate the measurements by variable. Default is False.
290                - quality_flags (bool, optional): Whether to include quality flag data. Default is False.
291
292                Returns:
293                -----------
294                - A DataFrame containing the measurements.
295
296            """         
297            #print('Get measurements', station, startDate, endDate, variables)
298            endpoint = 'services/measurements/v2/stations/%s/measurements/%s' % (station, dataset)
299
300            dateSplit = self.__splitDateRange(startDate, endDate)
301            series = []
302            seriesHolder = {}
303
304            for index, row in dateSplit.iterrows():
305                params = {'start': row['start'].strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ'), 'end': row['end'].strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ')}
306                if variables and isinstance(variables, list) and len(variables) == 1:
307                    params['variable'] = variables[0]
308                response = self.__request(endpoint, params)
309                if 'results' in response and len(response['results']) >= 1 and 'series' in response['results'][0] and len(
310                    response['results'][0]['series']) >= 1 and 'values' in response['results'][0]['series'][0]:
311
312                    for result in response['results']:
313                        if 'series' in result and len(result['series']) >= 1 and 'values' in result['series'][0]:
314                            for serie in result['series']:
315
316                                columns = serie['columns']
317                                observations = serie['values']
318
319                                time_index = columns.index('time')
320                                quality_index = columns.index('quality')
321                                variable_index = columns.index('variable')
322                                sensor_index = columns.index('sensor')
323                                value_index = columns.index('value')
324
325                                # Create list of unique variables within the retrieved observations.
326                                if not isinstance(variables, list) or len(variables) == 0:
327                                    shortcodes = list(set(list(map(lambda x: x[variable_index], observations))))
328                                else:
329                                    shortcodes = variables
330
331                                for shortcode in shortcodes:
332
333                                    # Create list of timeserie elements for this variable with predefined format [time, value, sensor, quality].
334                                    timeserie = list(map(lambda x: [x[time_index], x[value_index] if x[quality_index] == 1 else np.nan, x[sensor_index], x[quality_index]],
335                                                        list(filter(lambda x: x[variable_index] == shortcode, observations))))
336
337                                    if shortcode in seriesHolder:
338                                        seriesHolder[shortcode] = seriesHolder[shortcode] + timeserie
339                                    else:
340                                        seriesHolder[shortcode] = timeserie
341
342                                    # Clean up scope.
343                                    del timeserie
344
345                                # Clean up scope.
346                                del columns
347                                del observations
348                                del shortcodes
349
350                    # Clean up scope and free memory.
351                    del response
352                    gc.collect()
353
354            for shortcode in seriesHolder:
355                # Check if there are duplicate entries in this timeseries (multiple sensors for same variable).
356                timestamps = list(map(lambda x: x[0], seriesHolder[shortcode]))
357
358                if len(timestamps) > len(set(timestamps)):
359                    # Split observations per sensor.
360                    print('Split observations for %s per sensor' % shortcode)
361                    sensors = list(set(list(map(lambda x: x[2], seriesHolder[shortcode]))))
362                    for sensor in sensors:
363                        sensorSerie = list(filter(lambda x: x[2] == sensor, seriesHolder[shortcode]))
364                        timestamps = list(map(lambda x: pd.Timestamp(x[0]), sensorSerie))
365                        values = list(map(lambda x: x[1], sensorSerie))
366                        serie = pd.Series(values, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.float64)
367                        if quality_flags:
368                            q_flag = list(map(lambda x: x[3], sensorSerie))
369                            serie = pd.Series(q_flag, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.int32)
370                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (station, sensor, 'Q_FLAG')))
371                            continue
372                        if len(variables)==1:
373                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s' % (station, sensor)))
374                        else:
375                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (shortcode, station, sensor)))
376
377                        # Clean up scope.
378                        del sensorSerie
379                        del timestamps
380                        del values
381                        del serie
382                else:
383                    # print(pd.DataFrame(seriesHolder[shortcode]))
384                    values = list(map(lambda x: x[1], seriesHolder[shortcode]))
385                    serie = pd.Series(values, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.float64)
386
387                    if len(values) > 0:
388                        if quality_flags:
389                            q_flag = list(map(lambda x: x[3], seriesHolder[shortcode]))
390                            serie = pd.Series(q_flag, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.int32)
391                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s' % (station, 'Q_FLAG')))
392                            continue
393                                # series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (station, 'quality_flag')))
394                        sensors = list(set(list(map(lambda x: x[2], seriesHolder[shortcode]))))
395                        serie = pd.Series(values, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.float64)
396                        if len(variables) == 1:
397                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s' % (station, sensors[0])))
398                        else:
399                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (shortcode, station, sensors[0])))
400
401                    # Clean up scope.
402                    del values
403                    del serie
404
405                # Clean up memory.
406                gc.collect()
407
408            # Clean up.
409            del seriesHolder
410            gc.collect()
411
412            # Merge all series together.
413            if len(series) > 0:
414                df = pd.concat(series, axis=1, sort=True)
415            else:
416                df = pd.DataFrame()
417
418            # Clean up memory.
419            del series
420            gc.collect()
421            # check if dataframe is empty
422            if df.empty:
423                # add the date range in the dataframe and the column as the station filled with NaN
424                df = pd.DataFrame(index=pd.date_range(start=startDate, end=endDate, tz='UTC', freq='5min'), columns=[f'{station}'])
425            if quality_flags:
426                if aggregate:
427                    return self.aggregate_qualityflags(df)
428                else:
429                    return df
430            else:
431                if aggregate:
432                    return self.aggregate_variables(df)
433                else:
434                    return df

def get_stations_info(self, station=None, multipleStations=[], countrycode=None): 
 73    def get_stations_info(self, station=None, multipleStations=[], countrycode=None):
 74        """
 75        Retrieves information about weather stations from an API endpoint and returns relevant information based on the parameters passed to it.
 76
 77        Parameters:
 78        -----------
 79        - station (str, optional): Code for a single station to retrieve information for. Defaults to None.
 80        - multipleStations (list, optional): List of station codes to retrieve information for multiple stations. Defaults to [].
 81        - countrycode (str, optional): Country code to retrieve information for all stations located in the country. Defaults to None.
 82
 83        Returns:
 84        -----------
 85        - pandas.DataFrame: DataFrame containing information about the requested weather stations.
 86
 87        """
 88        # Make API request and convert response to DataFrame
 89        response = self.__request(endpoints['STATION_INFO'], {'sort':'code'})
 90        info = pd.json_normalize(response['data']).drop('id', axis=1)
 91
 92        # remove columns with TH in the code
 93        info = info.drop(labels=info['code'][info.code.str.contains('TH')].index, axis=0)
 94        
 95        # Filter DataFrame based on parameters
 96        if station:
 97            return info[info['code'] == station.upper()]
 98        elif len(multipleStations) >= 1:
 99            return info[info['code'].isin(multipleStations)]
100        elif countrycode:
101            info = info[info['location.countrycode'] == f'{countrycode.upper()}']
102            return info.drop(labels=info['code'][info.code.str.contains('TH')].index, axis=0)
103        else:
104            return info

Retrieves information about weather stations from an API endpoint and returns relevant information based on the parameters passed to it.

Parameters:

  • station (str, optional): Code for a single station to retrieve information for. Defaults to None.
  • multipleStations (list, optional): List of station codes to retrieve information for multiple stations. Defaults to [].
  • countrycode (str, optional): Country code to retrieve information for all stations located in the country. Defaults to None.

Returns:

  • pandas.DataFrame: DataFrame containing information about the requested weather stations.

108        """
109        Retrieves information about available weather variables from an API endpoint.

112        -----------

114        """

116        response = self.__request(endpoints['VARIABLES'], {})
117        variables = {}
118        if 'data' in response and isinstance(response['data'], list):
119            for element in response['data']:
120                variables[element['variable']['shortcode']] = element['variable']

def k_neighbours(self, station, number=5): 
147    def k_neighbours(self, station, number=5):
148        """
149        Returns a dictionary of the nearest neighbouring stations to the specified station.
150
151        Parameters:
152        -----------
153        - station (str): Code for the station to find neighbouring stations for.
154        - number (int, optional): Number of neighbouring stations to return. Defaults to 5.
155
156        Returns:
157        -----------
158        - dict: Dictionary containing the station codes and distances of the nearest neighbouring stations.
159        """
160        # Get latitude and longitude of specified station
161        lon, lat = self.get_stations_info(station)[['location.longitude', 'location.latitude']].values[0]
162        
163        # Calculate distances to all other stations and sort by distance
164        infostations = self.get_stations_info()
165        infostations['distance'] = infostations.apply(lambda row: hs.haversine((lat, lon), (row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude'])), axis=1)
166        infostations = infostations.sort_values('distance')
167        
168        # Create dictionary of nearest neighbouring stations and their distances
169        return dict(infostations[['code', 'distance']].head(number).values[1:])

  • number (int, optional): Number of neighbouring stations to return. Defaults to 5.

def station_status(self): 
172    def station_status(self):
173        """
174        Retrieves the status of all weather stations 
175
176        Returns:
177        -----------
178        - pandas.DataFrame: DataFrame containing the status of all weather stations.
179        """
180        # Make API request and convert response to DataFrame
181        response = self.__request(endpoints['STATION_STATUS'], {})
182        station_status = pd.json_normalize(response.json())
183        station_status = station_status.drop(labels=station_status['id'][station_status.id.str.contains('TH')].index, axis=0)
184
185        # create a column if active is true and offline_24h is false
186        def active(row):
187            if row['active'] == True and row['offline_24h'] == False:
188                return 1
189            else:
190                return 0
191        station_status['online'] = station_status.apply(active, axis=1)
192        return station_status

def aggregate_variables(self, dataframe): 
230    def aggregate_variables(self, dataframe):
231        """
232        Aggregates a pandas DataFrame of weather variables by summing values across each day.
233
234        Parameters:
235        -----------
236        - dataframe (pandas.DataFrame): DataFrame containing weather variable data.
237
238        Returns:
239        -----------
240        - pandas.DataFrame: DataFrame containing aggregated weather variable data, summed by day.
241        """
242        dataframe = dataframe.reset_index()
243        dataframe.rename(columns={'index':'Date'}, inplace=True)
244        # check if the column is all nan
245        if dataframe.iloc[:, 1].isnull().all():
246                return dataframe.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='Date', axis=0, 
247                                            freq='1D')).agg({f'{dataframe.columns[1]}': 
248                                                             lambda x: np.nan if x.isnull().all() 
249                                                             else x.isnull().sum()})    
250        else:
251                return dataframe.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='Date', axis=0, 
252                                            freq='1D')).sum()

Aggregates a pandas DataFrame of weather variables by summing values across each day.

Parameters:

  • dataframe (pandas.DataFrame): DataFrame containing weather variable data.

Returns:

  • pandas.DataFrame: DataFrame containing aggregated weather variable data, summed by day.
def aggregate_qualityflags(self, dataframe): 
255    def aggregate_qualityflags(self, dataframe):
256        """
257        Aggregate quality flags in a DataFrame by day.
258
259        Parameters:
260        -----------
261        - dataframe (pd.DataFrame): The DataFrame containing the measurements.
262
263        Returns:
264        -----------
265        - pd.DataFrame: A DataFrame with aggregated quality flags, where values greater than 1 are rounded up.
266
267        """
268        dataframe = dataframe.reset_index()
269        dataframe.rename(columns={'index': 'Date'}, inplace=True)
270        
271        # Group by day and calculate the mean. If value that day is greater than 1, get the ceiling.
272        return dataframe.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='Date', axis=0, freq='1D')).mean().applymap(lambda x: ceil(x) if x > 1 else x)

def get_measurements( self, station, startDate=None, endDate=None, variables=None, dataset='controlled', aggregate=False, quality_flags=False): 
278    def get_measurements(self, station, startDate=None, endDate=None, variables=None, dataset='controlled', aggregate=False, quality_flags=False):
279            """
280                Get measurements from a station.
281
282                Parameters:
283                -----------
284                - station (str): The station ID.
285                - startDate (str, optional): The start date of the measurement period in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
286                - endDate (str, optional): The end date of the measurement period in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
287                - variables (list, optional): The variables to retrieve measurements for. If None, all variables are retrieved.
288                - dataset (str, optional): The dataset to retrieve measurements from. Default is 'controlled'.
289                - aggregate (bool, optional): Whether to aggregate the measurements by variable. Default is False.
290                - quality_flags (bool, optional): Whether to include quality flag data. Default is False.
291
292                Returns:
293                -----------
294                - A DataFrame containing the measurements.
295
296            """         
297            #print('Get measurements', station, startDate, endDate, variables)
298            endpoint = 'services/measurements/v2/stations/%s/measurements/%s' % (station, dataset)
299
300            dateSplit = self.__splitDateRange(startDate, endDate)
301            series = []
302            seriesHolder = {}
303
304            for index, row in dateSplit.iterrows():
305                params = {'start': row['start'].strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ'), 'end': row['end'].strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ')}
306                if variables and isinstance(variables, list) and len(variables) == 1:
307                    params['variable'] = variables[0]
308                response = self.__request(endpoint, params)
309                if 'results' in response and len(response['results']) >= 1 and 'series' in response['results'][0] and len(
310                    response['results'][0]['series']) >= 1 and 'values' in response['results'][0]['series'][0]:
311
312                    for result in response['results']:
313                        if 'series' in result and len(result['series']) >= 1 and 'values' in result['series'][0]:
314                            for serie in result['series']:
315
316                                columns = serie['columns']
317                                observations = serie['values']
318
319                                time_index = columns.index('time')
320                                quality_index = columns.index('quality')
321                                variable_index = columns.index('variable')
322                                sensor_index = columns.index('sensor')
323                                value_index = columns.index('value')
324
325                                # Create list of unique variables within the retrieved observations.
326                                if not isinstance(variables, list) or len(variables) == 0:
327                                    shortcodes = list(set(list(map(lambda x: x[variable_index], observations))))
328                                else:
329                                    shortcodes = variables
330
331                                for shortcode in shortcodes:
332
333                                    # Create list of timeserie elements for this variable with predefined format [time, value, sensor, quality].
334                                    timeserie = list(map(lambda x: [x[time_index], x[value_index] if x[quality_index] == 1 else np.nan, x[sensor_index], x[quality_index]],
335                                                        list(filter(lambda x: x[variable_index] == shortcode, observations))))
336
337                                    if shortcode in seriesHolder:
338                                        seriesHolder[shortcode] = seriesHolder[shortcode] + timeserie
339                                    else:
340                                        seriesHolder[shortcode] = timeserie
341
342                                    # Clean up scope.
343                                    del timeserie
344
345                                # Clean up scope.
346                                del columns
347                                del observations
348                                del shortcodes
349
350                    # Clean up scope and free memory.
351                    del response
352                    gc.collect()
353
354            for shortcode in seriesHolder:
355                # Check if there are duplicate entries in this timeseries (multiple sensors for same variable).
356                timestamps = list(map(lambda x: x[0], seriesHolder[shortcode]))
357
358                if len(timestamps) > len(set(timestamps)):
359                    # Split observations per sensor.
360                    print('Split observations for %s per sensor' % shortcode)
361                    sensors = list(set(list(map(lambda x: x[2], seriesHolder[shortcode]))))
362                    for sensor in sensors:
363                        sensorSerie = list(filter(lambda x: x[2] == sensor, seriesHolder[shortcode]))
364                        timestamps = list(map(lambda x: pd.Timestamp(x[0]), sensorSerie))
365                        values = list(map(lambda x: x[1], sensorSerie))
366                        serie = pd.Series(values, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.float64)
367                        if quality_flags:
368                            q_flag = list(map(lambda x: x[3], sensorSerie))
369                            serie = pd.Series(q_flag, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.int32)
370                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (station, sensor, 'Q_FLAG')))
371                            continue
372                        if len(variables)==1:
373                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s' % (station, sensor)))
374                        else:
375                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (shortcode, station, sensor)))
376
377                        # Clean up scope.
378                        del sensorSerie
379                        del timestamps
380                        del values
381                        del serie
382                else:
383                    # print(pd.DataFrame(seriesHolder[shortcode]))
384                    values = list(map(lambda x: x[1], seriesHolder[shortcode]))
385                    serie = pd.Series(values, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.float64)
386
387                    if len(values) > 0:
388                        if quality_flags:
389                            q_flag = list(map(lambda x: x[3], seriesHolder[shortcode]))
390                            serie = pd.Series(q_flag, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.int32)
391                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s' % (station, 'Q_FLAG')))
392                            continue
393                                # series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (station, 'quality_flag')))
394                        sensors = list(set(list(map(lambda x: x[2], seriesHolder[shortcode]))))
395                        serie = pd.Series(values, index=pd.DatetimeIndex(timestamps), dtype=np.float64)
396                        if len(variables) == 1:
397                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s' % (station, sensors[0])))
398                        else:
399                            series.append(serie.to_frame('%s_%s_%s' % (shortcode, station, sensors[0])))
400
401                    # Clean up scope.
402                    del values
403                    del serie
404
405                # Clean up memory.
406                gc.collect()
407
408            # Clean up.
409            del seriesHolder
410            gc.collect()
411
412            # Merge all series together.
413            if len(series) > 0:
414                df = pd.concat(series, axis=1, sort=True)
415            else:
416                df = pd.DataFrame()
417
418            # Clean up memory.
419            del series
420            gc.collect()
421            # check if dataframe is empty
422            if df.empty:
423                # add the date range in the dataframe and the column as the station filled with NaN
424                df = pd.DataFrame(index=pd.date_range(start=startDate, end=endDate, tz='UTC', freq='5min'), columns=[f'{station}'])
425            if quality_flags:
426                if aggregate:
427                    return self.aggregate_qualityflags(df)
428                else:
429                    return df
430            else:
431                if aggregate:
432                    return self.aggregate_variables(df)
433                else:
434                    return df

524                df.to_csv(f'{csv_file}.csv')
525                return df.reindex(sorted(df.columns),axis=1) #sorted dataframe

Retrieves and aggregates quality flag data for multiple stations within a specified date range.

Parameters:

  • stations_list (list): A list of station codes for which to retrieve data.
  • startDate (str): The start date in 'YYYY-MM-DD' format.
  • endDate (str): The end date in 'YYYY-MM-DD' format.
  • csv_file (str, optional): The name of the CSV file to save the aggregated data. Default is None.

Returns:

  • pandas.DataFrame or None: A DataFrame containing the aggregated quality flag data for the specified stations, or None if an error occurs.

Raises: Exception: If an error occurs while retrieving data for a station.

536    # given the radius and the longitude and latitude of the gauging station, return the stations within
537    def stations_within_radius(self, radius, latitude, longitude, df=False):
538        """
539    Retrieves stations within a specified radius from a given latitude and longitude.
540
541    Parameters:
542    -----------
543    - radius (float): Radius (in kilometers) within which to search for stations.
544    - latitude (float): Latitude of the center point.
545    - longitude (float): Longitude of the center point.
546    - df (bool, optional): Flag indicating whether to return the result as a DataFrame. Defaults to False.
547
548    Returns:
549    - DataFrame or list: DataFrame or list containing the stations within the specified radius. If df is True, a DataFrame is returned with the columns 'code', 'location.latitude', 'location.longitude', and 'distance'. If df is False, a list of station codes is returned.
550
551    """
552        stations  = super().get_stations_info()
553        stations['distance'] = stations.apply(lambda row: hs.haversine((latitude, longitude), (row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude'])), axis=1)
554        infostations = stations[['code', 'location.latitude','location.longitude', 'distance']].sort_values('distance')
555        if df:
556            return infostations[infostations['distance'] <= radius]
557        else:
558            return infostations[infostations['distance'] <= radius].code.values

561    def stations_data_check(self, stations_list, percentage=1, start_date=None, end_date=None, data=None, variables=['pr'], csv_file=None):
562        """
563        Performs a data check on the stations' data and returns the stations with a percentage of missing data below a threshold.
564
565        Parameters:
566        -----------
567        - stations_list (list): List of station names or IDs.
568        - percentage (float, optional): Threshold percentage of missing data. Defaults to 1 (i.e., 100% missing data allowed).
569        - start_date (str, optional): Start date for the data range in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'. Defaults to None.
570        - end_date (str, optional): End date for the data range in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'. Defaults to None.
571        - data (DataFrame, optional): Preloaded data for the stations. Defaults to None.
572        - variables (list, optional): List of variables to consider for the data check. Defaults to ['pr'].
573        - csv_file (str, optional): File name for saving the data as a CSV file. Defaults to None.
574
575        Returns:
576        -----------
577        - DataFrame: DataFrame containing the stations' data with less than the specified percentage of missing data.
578
579        """
580        if data is None:
581            data = super().multiple_measurements(stations_list, startDate=start_date, endDate=end_date, variables=variables, csv_file=csv_file)
582
583        # Check the percentage of missing data and return the stations with less than the percentage of missing data
584        data.index = data.index.astype('datetime64[ns]')
585        data = data.dropna(axis=1, thresh=int(len(data) * percentage))
586        data.to_csv(f'{csv_file}.csv')
587        return data

589    def stations_lag(self, weather_stations_df, gauging_stations_df, gauging_station_columns, date=None, lag=3, above=False, below=False):
590        """
591        Calculates the lag between weather station data and gauging station data.
592
593        Parameters:
594        -----------
595        - weather_stations_df (DataFrame): DataFrame containing weather station data.
596        - gauging_stations_df (DataFrame): DataFrame containing gauging station data.
597        - gauging_station_columns (list): List of columns in the gauging_stations_df DataFrame to consider for lag calculation.
598        - date (str, optional): Start date for the analysis in the format 'dd/mm/yyyy'. Defaults to None, which takes the first date from gauging_stations_df.
599        - lag (int, optional): The lag value to consider for the correlation analysis. Defaults to 3.
600        - above (bool, optional): Flag indicating whether to return lag results for correlations above the threshold. Defaults to False.
601        - below (bool, optional): Flag indicating whether to return lag results for correlations below the threshold. Defaults to False.
602
603        Returns:
604        -----------
605        - dict or tuple: Dictionary or tuple containing the lag results, depending on the above and below flags. The dictionary has the following structure:
606                {
607                    'column_name': {
608                        'lag': lag_value,
609                        'coefficient': correlation_coefficient,
610                        'coefficient_list': list of correlation coefficients,
611                        'select_list': list of values from weather station data,
612                        'water_list': list of values from gauging station data
613                    },
614                    ...
615                }
616        - If both above and below flags are True, a tuple containing two dictionaries is returned: (above_thresh_lag, below_thresh_lag).
617
618        """
619        
620        if date is None:
621            date = gauging_stations_df.loc[0, gauging_station_columns[0]]
622        start_date = datetime.datetime.strptime(date, "%d/%m/%Y")
623        end_date = start_date + datetime.timedelta(len(gauging_stations_df)-1)
624        # get the ddataframe from start date to end date
625        df_fit = weather_stations_df[start_date:end_date]
626        # get the water data list
627        water_list = list(gauging_stations_df[f'{gauging_station_columns[1]}'])
628        above_thresh_lag = dict()
629        below_thresh_lag = dict()
630        # get the lag for every column against the water data 
631        for cols in df_fit.columns:
632            select_list = list(df_fit[cols])
633            coefficient_list = list(sm.tsa.stattools.ccf(select_list,water_list, adjusted=False))
634            a = np.argmax(coefficient_list)
635            b = coefficient_list[a]
636            if a > lag:
637                above_thresh_lag[cols] = {
638                    'lag': a,
639                    'coefficient': b,
640                    'coefficient_list': coefficient_list,
641                    'select_list': select_list,
642                    'water_list' : water_list
643                }
644            else:
645                below_thresh_lag[cols] = {
646                    'lag': a,
647                    'coefficient': b,
648                    'coefficient_list': coefficient_list,
649                    'select_list': select_list,
650                    'water_list' : water_list
651                }
652        if above and below:
653            return above_thresh_lag, below_thresh_lag
654        elif above:
655            return above_thresh_lag
656        elif below:
657            return below_thresh_lag
658        
659        
660    def plot_figs(self, weather_stations, water_list, threshold_list, save=False, dpi=500, date='11-02-2021'):
661        """
662        Plots figures showing the relationship between rainfall and water level/stage against time.
663
664        Parameters:
665        -----------
666        - weather_stations (DataFrame): DataFrame containing weather station data.
667        - water_list (list): List of water levels/stages.
668        - threshold_list (list): List of columns in the weather_stations DataFrame to plot.
669        - save (bool, optional): Flag indicating whether to save the figures as PNG files. Defaults to False.
670        - dpi (int, optional): Dots per inch for saving the figures. Defaults to 500.
671        - date (str, optional): Start date for plotting in the format 'dd-mm-yyyy'. Defaults to '11-02-2021'.
672
673        Returns:
674        -----------
675        - Displays the images of the plots. and if save is set to true saves the images in the current directory.
676
677        """
678        start_date = datetime.datetime.strptime(date, "%d-%m-%Y")
679        end_date = start_date + datetime.timedelta(len(water_list)-1)
680        # weather_stations = weather_stations.set_index('Date')
681        df_plot = weather_stations[start_date:end_date]
682        df_plot = df_plot[threshold_list].reset_index()
683        df_plot.rename(columns={'index':'Date'}, inplace=True)
684        
685        
686        plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (15, 9)
687        print('Begin plotting!')
688        
689        for cols in df_plot.columns[1:]:
690            fig, ax1 = plt.subplots()
691            color = 'tab:blue'
692            ax1.set_xlabel(f'Time', fontsize=24, weight='bold')
693            ax1.set_ylabel(f'Rainfall {cols} (mm)', color=color, fontsize=24, weight='bold')
694            ax1.bar(pd.to_datetime(df_plot['Date'], format="%d/%m/%Y"), df_plot[f'{cols}'], color=color, width=4, alpha=1.0)
695            ax1.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=color, labelsize=24)
696            ax1.tick_params(axis='x')
697            ax1.set_xticklabels(df_plot['Date'], fontsize=21, weight='bold')
698            ax1.grid(color='gray', linestyle='--', linewidth=0.8)
699            ax1.set(facecolor="white")
700            ax2 = ax1.twinx()  # instantiate a second axes that shares the same x-axis
701
702            color = 'tab:red'
703            ax2.set_ylabel('Water level/Stage (m)', color=color, fontsize=24, weight='bold')
704            ax2.plot(pd.to_datetime(df_plot['Date'], format="%d/%m/%Y"), water_list, color=color, linewidth=4)
705            ax2.tick_params(axis='y', labelcolor=color, labelsize=24)
706            ax2.set(facecolor="white")
707            plt.title('Stage and Rainfall against Time', fontsize=22, weight='bold')
708
709            date_form = DateFormatter("%m-%y")
710            ax1.xaxis.set_major_formatter(date_form)
711            fig.tight_layout()
712
713            if save:
714                fig.savefig(f'{cols}.png', dpi=dpi)

723    def get_stations_info(self, station=None, multipleStations=[], countrycode=None):
724        return super().get_stations_info(station, multipleStations, countrycode)

726    # Get the centre point of the address
727    def centre_point(self, address):
728        """
729        This method retrieves the latitude and longitude coordinates of a given address using the Nominatim API.
730        
731        Parameters:
732        -----------
733        - address : str
734            The address of the location you want to retrieve the coordinates for.
735            
736        Returns:
737        --------
738        - Tuple (float, float)
739            The latitude and longitude coordinates of the location.
740        """
741        url = 'https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search/' + urllib.parse.quote(address) +'?format=json'
742        return requests.get(url).json()[0]['lat'], requests.get(url).json()[0]['lon']
743
744    # Get the new radius of the address
745    def calculate_new_point(self, lat, lon, distance, bearing):
746        """
747        Calculates a new geographic point based on the given latitude, longitude,
748        distance and bearing.
749
750        Parameters:
751        -----------
752        - lat (float): The latitude of the starting point in decimal degrees.
753        - lon (float): The longitude of the starting point in decimal degrees.
754        - distance (float): The distance in kilometers from the starting point to the new point.
755        - bearing (float): The bearing in degrees from the starting point to the new point,
756            measured clockwise from true north.
757
758        Returns:
759        -----------
760        - Tuple[float, float]: A tuple containing the latitude and longitude of the new point,
761        respectively, in decimal degrees.
762        """
763        distance = distance * 1000
764        # Convert degrees to radians
765        lat = math.radians(lat)
766        lon = math.radians(lon)
767        bearing = math.radians(bearing)
768        
769        # Earth radius in meters
770        R = 6371000
771        
772        # Calculate new latitude
773        lat2 = math.asin(math.sin(lat) * math.cos(distance / R) +
774                        math.cos(lat) * math.sin(distance / R) * math.cos(bearing))
775                        
776        # Calculate new longitude
777        lon2 = lon + math.atan2(math.sin(bearing) * math.sin(distance / R) * math.cos(lat),
778                                math.cos(distance / R) - math.sin(lat) * math.sin(lat2))
779        
780        # Convert back to degrees
781        lat2 = math.degrees(lat2)
782        lon2 = math.degrees(lon2)
783        
784        return lat2, lon2
785    
786
787    # Get the bounding box of the address
788    def compute_filter(self, lat, lon, distance):
789        """
790        Calculates the bounding box coordinates for a given location and distance.
791
792        Parameters:
793        -----------
794        - lat (float): The latitude of the location.
795        - lon (float): The longitude of the location.
796        - distance (float): The distance from the location, in kilometers, to the edge of the bounding box.
797
798        Returns:
799        -----------
800        - A tuple containing four floats representing the bounding box coordinates: (min_lat, min_lon, max_lat, max_lon).
801        """
802        points = []
803        g1 = []
804        for i in range(0, 360, 45):
805            points.append(self.calculate_new_point(lat, lon, distance, i))
806        g1 = [min(p[0] for p in points), min(p[1] for p in points)]
807        g2 = [max(p[0] for p in points), max(p[1] for p in points)]
808        # print(g1, '\n', g2)
809        return g1[0], g1[1], g2[0], g2[1]
810

814    def filter_stations(self, address, distance, startDate=None, endDate=None, csvfile='pr_clog_flags.csv'):
815        """
816        This method filters weather station data within a certain distance from a given address.
817        
818        Parameters:
819        -----------
820        - address (str): Address to center the bounding box around.
821        - distance (float): The distance (in kilometers) from the center to the edge of the bounding box.
822        - startDate (str): The start date for filtering the weather station data in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
823        - endDate (str): The end date for filtering the weather station data in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
824        - csvfile (str): The name of the csv file containing the weather station data.
825        
826        Returns:
827        -----------
828        - pandas.DataFrame: The filtered weather station data within the bounding box.
829        """   
830        centre = self.centre_point(address)
831        lat, lon = float(centre[0]), float(centre[1])  
832        stations = super().stations_within_radius(distance, lat, lon, df=False)
833        # lat, lon = self.centre_point(address)
834        # min_lat, min_lon, max_lat, max_lon = self.compute_filter(float(lat), float(lon), distance)
835        # stations = super().get_stations_info()
836        # bounds = list(stations['code'][(stations['location.longitude'] >= min_lon)
837        #                                 & (stations['location.longitude'] <= max_lon)
838        #                                 & (stations['location.latitude'] >= min_lat)
839        #                                     & (stations['location.latitude'] <= max_lat)])
840        
841        # read the csv file
842        ke_chec = pd.read_csv(csvfile)
843        ke_chec.Date = ke_chec.Date.astype('datetime64[ns]')
844        # print(ke_chec.info())
845
846        # ke_chec = ke_chec.set_index('Date')
847        if startDate and endDate:
848            startdate = dateutil.parser.parse(startDate)
849            enddate = dateutil.parser.parse(endDate)
850            begin = ke_chec['Date'][ke_chec['Date'] == startdate].index.to_numpy()[0]
851            end = ke_chec['Date'][ke_chec['Date'] == enddate].index.to_numpy()[0]
852            ke_chec = ke_chec.iloc[begin:end+1]
853            ke_chec = ke_chec.set_index('Date')
854
855            return ke_chec[[i for i in ke_chec.columns if i.split('_')[0] in stations]]
856        else:
857            ke_chec = ke_chec.set_index('Date')
858            return ke_chec[[i for i in ke_chec.columns if i.split('_')[0] in stations]]
859

861    # A list of filtered stations
862    def filter_stations_list(self, address, distance=100):
863        """
864        Filters stations based on their proximity to a given address and returns a list of station codes that fall within the specified distance.
865        
866        Parameters:
867        -----------
868        - address (str): Address to filter stations by.
869        - distance (float, optional): Maximum distance (in kilometers) between the stations and the address. Default is 100 km.
870        
871        Returns:
872        -----------
873        - List of station codes that fall within the specified distance from the given address.
874        """
875        return list(set([i.split('_')[0] for i in self.filter_stations(f'{address}', distance).columns if i.split('_')[-1] != 'clogFlag']))

877    # get clogs for a certain duration based on quality objects file
878    def clogs(self, startdate, enddate, flags_json='qualityobjects.json', as_csv=False, csv_file=None):
879        """
880        Generate clog flags DataFrame based on start and end dates.
881
882        Parameters:
883        -----------
884        - startdate (str): Start date in 'YYYY-MM-DD' format.
885        - enddate (str): End date in 'YYYY-MM-DD' format.
886        - flags_json (str, optional): Path to the JSON file containing clog flags data. Defaults to 'qualityobjects.json'.
887        - questionable (bool, optional): Whether to return questionable clog flags. Defaults to False.
888        - as_csv (bool, optional): Whether to save the resulting DataFrame as a CSV file. Defaults to False.
889        - csv_file (str, optional): Name of the CSV file to save. Only applicable if as_csv is True. Defaults to None.
890
891        Returns:
892        -----------
893        - pandas.DataFrame: DataFrame containing the clog flags.
894
895        """
896
897        json_data = pd.read_json(flags_json)
898        startdate = datetime.datetime.strptime(startdate, '%Y-%m-%d')
899        enddate = datetime.datetime.strptime(enddate, '%Y-%m-%d')
900
901        # merge the sensorcode and the stationcode to equate to the station_sensor format 
902        json_data['station_sensor'] = json_data['stationCode'] + '_' + json_data['sensorCode']
903        # convert the start and end time to datetime format datetime[ns]
904        json_data['startDate'] = json_data['startDate'].astype('datetime64[ns]')
905        json_data['endDate'] = pd.to_datetime([dateutil.parser.parse(i).strftime('%Y-%m-%d') for i in json_data['endDate']])
906
907        json_data = json_data.drop(['stationCode', 'sensorCode'], axis=1)
908        json_data = json_data[['description', 'startDate', 'endDate', 'station_sensor']]
909
910        other_failure = list(json_data[json_data['description'].str.contains('batter')].index)
911        clog = list(json_data[~json_data['description'].str.contains('batter')].index)
912
913        clog_flags = pd.DataFrame(pd.date_range(startdate, enddate, freq='D'), columns=['Date'])
914
915        clogs_dict = dict()
916        for i in json_data.station_sensor.unique():
917            clogs_dict[f'{i}_clogFlags'] = [np.nan for i in range(len(clog_flags))]
918
919        flags_df = pd.concat([clog_flags, pd.DataFrame(clogs_dict)], axis=1)
920
921        def subset_flags_df(startdate, enddate, column, val):
922            """
923            Update a subset of flags in the DataFrame with a specific value.
924
925            Args:
926                startdate (datetime): Start date of the subset.
927                enddate (datetime): End date of the subset.
928                column (str): Name of the column to update.
929                val: Value to fill in the specified column.
930
931            Returns:
932                None
933
934            """
935            # print(f'Updating {column} from {startdate} to {enddate} to {val}')
936            flags_df.loc[((flags_df['Date'] >= startdate) & (flags_df['Date'] <= enddate)), column] = val
937
938        for ind, row in json_data.iterrows():
939            if ind in other_failure:
940                if row['startDate'] >= startdate and row['endDate'] <= enddate:
941                    subset_flags_df(row['startDate'], row['endDate'], f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 2)
942                elif row['startDate'] >= startdate and row['endDate'] > enddate:
943                    subset_flags_df(row['startDate'], enddate, f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 2)
944                elif row['startDate'] < startdate and row['endDate'] <= enddate:
945                    subset_flags_df(startdate, row['endDate'], f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 2)
946                elif row['startDate'] < startdate and row['endDate'] > enddate:
947                    subset_flags_df(startdate, enddate, f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 2)
948            elif ind in clog:
949                if row['startDate'] >= startdate and row['endDate'] <= enddate:
950                    subset_flags_df(row['startDate'], row['endDate'], f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 1)
951                elif row['startDate'] >= startdate and row['endDate'] > enddate:
952                    subset_flags_df(row['startDate'], enddate, f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 1)
953                elif row['startDate'] < startdate and row['endDate'] <= enddate:
954                    subset_flags_df(startdate, row['endDate'], f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 1)
955                elif row['startDate'] < startdate and row['endDate'] > enddate:
956                    subset_flags_df(startdate, enddate, f"{row['station_sensor']}_clogFlags", 1)
957
958        flags_df = flags_df.set_index('Date')
959        flags_df = flags_df.reindex(sorted(flags_df.columns), axis=1)
960
961        if as_csv:
962            if csv_file is not None:
963                flags_df.to_csv(f'{csv_file}.csv', index=True)
964                return flags_df
965            else:
966                flags_df.to_csv('clog_flags.csv', index=True)
967                return flags_df
968        else:
969            return flags_df
Filter(apiKey, apiSecret)

def calculate_new_point(self, lat, lon, distance, bearing): 
745    def calculate_new_point(self, lat, lon, distance, bearing):
746        """
747        Calculates a new geographic point based on the given latitude, longitude,
748        distance and bearing.
749
750        Parameters:
751        -----------
752        - lat (float): The latitude of the starting point in decimal degrees.
753        - lon (float): The longitude of the starting point in decimal degrees.
754        - distance (float): The distance in kilometers from the starting point to the new point.
755        - bearing (float): The bearing in degrees from the starting point to the new point,
756            measured clockwise from true north.
757
758        Returns:
759        -----------
760        - Tuple[float, float]: A tuple containing the latitude and longitude of the new point,
761        respectively, in decimal degrees.
762        """
763        distance = distance * 1000
764        # Convert degrees to radians
765        lat = math.radians(lat)
766        lon = math.radians(lon)
767        bearing = math.radians(bearing)
768        
769        # Earth radius in meters
770        R = 6371000
771        
772        # Calculate new latitude
773        lat2 = math.asin(math.sin(lat) * math.cos(distance / R) +
774                        math.cos(lat) * math.sin(distance / R) * math.cos(bearing))
775                        
776        # Calculate new longitude
777        lon2 = lon + math.atan2(math.sin(bearing) * math.sin(distance / R) * math.cos(lat),
778                                math.cos(distance / R) - math.sin(lat) * math.sin(lat2))
779        
780        # Convert back to degrees
781        lat2 = math.degrees(lat2)
782        lon2 = math.degrees(lon2)
783        
784        return lat2, lon2

Calculates a new geographic point based on the given latitude, longitude, distance and bearing.

Parameters:

  • lat (float): The latitude of the starting point in decimal degrees.
  • lon (float): The longitude of the starting point in decimal degrees.
  • distance (float): The distance in kilometers from the starting point to the new point.
  • bearing (float): The bearing in degrees from the starting point to the new point, measured clockwise from true north.

Returns:

  • Tuple[float, float]: A tuple containing the latitude and longitude of the new point, respectively, in decimal degrees.

class Interactive_maps(retreive_data): 
 972class Interactive_maps(retreive_data):

 974    def __init__(self, apiKey, apiSecret):
 975        super().__init__(apiKey, apiSecret)

 977    def draw_map(self, map_center):
 978        """
 979        Creates a Folium map centered on the specified location and adds markers for each weather station in the area.
 980
 981        Parameters:
 982        -----------
 983        - map_center: a tuple with the latitude and longitude of the center of the map
 984
 985        Returns:
 986        -----------
 987        - A Folium map object
 988        """
 989
 990        #  retrieve the stations data
 991        stations = super().get_stations_info()[['code', 'location.longitude', 'location.latitude']]
 992        # create a map centered on a specific location
 993
 994        my_map = folium.Map(location=map_center, min_zoom=5, max_zoom=30, zoom_start=12, tiles='cartodbpositron')
 995        for _, row in stations.iterrows():
 996            folium.Marker([row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude']], tooltip=row['code']).add_to(my_map)
 997
 998
 999        # fit the map bounds to the markers' locations
1000        marker_locations = [[row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude']] for _, row in stations.iterrows()]
1001        my_map.fit_bounds(marker_locations)
1002
1003        # display the map
1004        return my_map

1007    def animation_image(self, sensors,  start_date, end_date, day=100, T=10, interval=500, data=None):
1008        '''
1009        Creates an animation of pollutant levels for a given range of days and valid sensors.
1010
1011        Parameters:
1012        -----------
1013        - data (DataFrame): A pandas DataFrame containing station data defaults to none reads pr_clog_flags if none.
1014        - sensors (list): A list of valid sensor names.
1015        - day (int): The starting day of the animation (default is 100).
1016        - T (int): The range of days for the animation (default is 10).
1017        - interval (int): The interval between frames in milliseconds (default is 500).
1018
1019        Returns:
1020        -----------
1021        - HTML: An HTML object containing the animation.
1022        '''
1023        if not data:
1024            data = pd.read_csv('pr_clog_flags.csv')
1025            data['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Date'])
1026            data = data.loc[(data['Date'] >= start_date) & (data['Date'] <= end_date)]
1027
1028        
1029        data1 = np.array(data[sensors].iloc[day:day+1]).T
1030        data1 /= np.max(data1)
1031        # Create figure and axis
1032        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1033
1034        # Define function to update matrix data
1035        def update(i):
1036            # Generate new data
1037            new_data =  np.array(data[sensors].iloc[int(day):int(day+1+i)]).T
1038            new_data /= np.max(new_data)
1039
1040            # Update matrix data
1041            im.set_array(new_data)
1042
1043            return [im]
1044
1045        # Create matrix plot
1046        im = ax.imshow(data1, aspect='auto', interpolation=None)
1047
1048        # Create animation
1049        ani = animation.FuncAnimation(fig, update, frames=range(T), interval=interval, blit=False)
1050
1051        plt.close()
1052
1053        return HTML(ani.to_jshtml())

1055    # create animation grid
1056    def animation_grid(self, mu_pred, xi, xj, valid_station_df, clogged_station_df, T=10):
1057        """
1058        Creates an animation of the predicted data on a grid over time.
1059
1060        Parameters:
1061        -----------
1062        - mu_pred (ndarray): The predicted data on a grid over time.
1063        - xi (ndarray): The x-coordinates of the grid.
1064        - xj (ndarray): The y-coordinates of the grid.
1065        - valid_station_df (DataFrame): A DataFrame containing the information of the valid stations.
1066        - clogged_station_df (DataFrame): A DataFrame containing the information of the clogged stations.
1067        - T (int): The number of time steps.
1068
1069        Returns:
1070        -----------
1071        - HTML: The animation as an HTML object.
1072        """
1073        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1074
1075        def animate(t):
1076            ax.clear()
1077            ax.set_title('Time step {}'.format(t))
1078            ax.pcolor(xi, xj, mu_pred[:, t:t+1].reshape(xi.shape), shading='auto')
1079            ax.plot(valid_station_df['Longitude'], valid_station_df['Latitude'], '.')
1080            ax.plot(clogged_station_df['Longitude'], clogged_station_df['Latitude'], 'r.')
1081
1082        ani = animation.FuncAnimation(fig, animate, frames=T, interval=500, blit=False)
1083        plt.close()
1084        
1085        return HTML(ani.to_jshtml())

1089    def plot_station(self, ws, df_rainfall):
1090        """
1091        Plot the rainfall data for a specific weather station.
1092
1093        Parameters:
1094        -----------
1095        - ws: string, the code of the weather station to plot
1096        - df_rainfall: DataFrame, a pandas DataFrame with rainfall data
1097
1098        Returns:
1099        -----------
1100        - None if no data is available for the specified station
1101        - a Matplotlib figure showing rainfall data for the specified station otherwise
1102        """
1103        # filter columns based on station code and type (sensor or clog flag)
1104        sensors = [x for x in list(df_rainfall.keys()) if ws in x and 'clog' not in x]
1105        clog_flags = [x for x in list(df_rainfall.keys()) if ws in x and 'clog' in x]
1106
1107        # check if any data is present
1108        if not sensors and not clog_flags:
1109            return None
1110
1111        # create subplots
1112        try:
1113            fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=len(sensors)+len(clog_flags), ncols=1, figsize=(13,13))
1114        except:
1115            return None
1116
1117        # plot data for sensors and clog flags
1118        
1119        # plot data for sensors and clog flags
1120        df_rainfall[sensors].plot(subplots=True, ax=ax[:len(sensors)])
1121        df_rainfall[clog_flags].plot(subplots=True, ax=ax[len(sensors):])
1122
1123        # adjust spacing between subplots
1124        plt.subplots_adjust(hspace=0.5)
1125
1126        # add x and y axis labels and title
1127        plt.xlabel('Time')
1128        plt.ylabel('Rainfall')
1129        plt.suptitle('Rainfall data for sensors and clog flags at station {}'.format(ws))
1130        plt.close()
1131        return fig
1132
1133
1134    # Encode the image
1135    def encode_image(self, ws, df_rainfall):
1136        """
1137        Encodes a station's rainfall data plot as a base64-encoded image.
1138
1139        Parameters:
1140        -----------
1141        - ws (str): the code for the station to encode the image for
1142        - df_rainfall (pandas.DataFrame): a DataFrame containing the rainfall data for all stations
1143        
1144        Returns:
1145        -----------
1146        - str: a string containing an HTML image tag with the encoded image data, or a message indicating no data is available for the given station
1147        """
1148        figure = self.plot_station(ws, df_rainfall)
1149        if figure is not None:
1150            figure.tight_layout()
1151            buf = BytesIO()
1152            figure.savefig(buf, format='png')
1153            plt.close() # close the figure object to remove the subplot
1154            buf.seek(0)
1155            # Encode the image data as base64
1156            image_data = base64.b64encode(buf.read()).decode('utf-8')
1157            return '<img src="data:image/png;base64,{}">'.format(image_data)
1158        else:
1159            return 'No data available for station {}'.format(ws)

1163    def get_map(self, subset_list, start_date=None, end_date=None, data_values=False, csv_file='pr_clog_flags.csv', min_zoom=8, max_zoom=11, width=2000, height=2000, png_resolution=300):
1164        """
1165        Creates a Folium map showing the locations of the weather stations in the given subsets.
1166
1167        Parameters:
1168        -----------
1169        - subset_list : list of lists of str
1170            List of subsets of weather stations, where each subset is a list of station codes.
1171        - start_date : str, optional
1172            Start date in the format YYYY-MM-DD, default is None.
1173        - end_date : str, optional
1174            End date in the format YYYY-MM-DD, default is None.
1175        - data_values : bool, optional
1176            If True, the map markers will display a plot of rainfall data, default is False.
1177        - csv_file : str, optional
1178            The name of the CSV file containing the rainfall data, default is 'pr_clog_flags.csv'.
1179        - min_zoom : int, optional
1180            The minimum zoom level of the map, default is 8.
1181        - max_zoom : int, optional
1182            The maximum zoom level of the map, default is 11.
1183        - width : int, optional
1184            The width of the map in pixels, default is 850.
1185        - height : int, optional
1186            The height of the map in pixels, default is 850.
1187        - png_resolution : int, optional
1188            The resolution of the PNG image if data_values is True, default is 300.
1189
1190        Returns:
1191        --------
1192        - my_map : folium.folium.Map
1193            A Folium map object showing the locations of the weather stations in the given subsets.
1194        """
1195        # Read the csv file 
1196        df_rainfall = pd.read_csv(csv_file)
1197        df_rainfall['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_rainfall['Date'])
1198        df_rainfall= df_rainfall.set_index('Date')
1199        if start_date and end_date:
1200            df_rainfall = df_rainfall[start_date:end_date]
1201        
1202        # get the stations data to map the centre
1203        stations = super().get_stations_info()[['code', 'location.longitude', 'location.latitude']] # get the stations data to obtain the distance
1204        # subset1_stations = list(set([clog.split('_')[0] for clog in subset1])) # ideally the fine stations
1205        # subset2_stations = list(set([clog.split('_')[0] for clog in subset2])) # clogged stations
1206        # union_stations = list(set(subset1_stations).union(subset2_stations))
1207        
1208        # Changing to use with multiple subsets
1209        joined = set([j for i in subset_list for j in i])
1210
1211        # Find the centre from the union of the stations
1212        stations_df = stations[stations['code'].isin(list(joined))]
1213        map_center = [stations_df['location.latitude'].mean(), stations_df['location.longitude'].mean()]
1214
1215        # get the map center
1216        # map_center = [stations['location.latitude'].mean(), stations['location.longitude'].mean()]
1217
1218        # create a map centered on a specific location
1219        my_map = folium.Map(map_center, min_zoom=min_zoom, max_zoom=max_zoom, zoom_start=8, tiles='cartodbpositron', width=width, height=height, png_resolution=png_resolution)
1220        # add a measure control to the map
1221        measure_control = MeasureControl(position='topleft', active_color='red', completed_color='red', primary_length_unit='meters')
1222        my_map.add_child(measure_control)
1223
1224        # add the markers to the map
1225        color_markers = ['blue', 'red', 'green', 'purple', 'orange', 'black', 'beige', 'yellow', 'violet', 'brown']
1226        for _, row in stations.iterrows():
1227            # loop throught the list subsets and create markers for each subset
1228            for num, subs in enumerate(subset_list):
1229                if row['code'] in subs:
1230                    # Create an IFrame object with the image as the content
1231                    if data_values:
1232                        popup_iframe = folium.IFrame(html=f"{self.encode_image(row['code'], df_rainfall)}", width=width//8, height=height//8)
1233                        folium.Marker([row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude']], popup=folium.Popup(popup_iframe),  
1234                                    tooltip=row['code'], icon=folium.Icon(color=color_markers[num])).add_to(my_map)
1235                    else:
1236                        folium.Marker([row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude']], 
1237                                    tooltip=row['code'], icon=folium.Icon(color=color_markers[num])).add_to(my_map)
1238        
1239        # display the map
1240        return my_map

1213        map_center = [stations_df['location.latitude'].mean(), stations_df['location.longitude'].mean()]
1214
1215        # get the map center
1216        # map_center = [stations['location.latitude'].mean(), stations['location.longitude'].mean()]
1217
1218        # create a map centered on a specific location
1219        my_map = folium.Map(map_center, min_zoom=min_zoom, max_zoom=max_zoom, zoom_start=8, tiles='cartodbpositron', width=width, height=height, png_resolution=png_resolution)
1220        # add a measure control to the map
1221        measure_control = MeasureControl(position='topleft', active_color='red', completed_color='red', primary_length_unit='meters')
1222        my_map.add_child(measure_control)
1223
1224        # add the markers to the map
1225        color_markers = ['blue', 'red', 'green', 'purple', 'orange', 'black', 'beige', 'yellow', 'violet', 'brown']
1226        for _, row in stations.iterrows():
1227            # loop throught the list subsets and create markers for each subset
1228            for num, subs in enumerate(subset_list):
1229                if row['code'] in subs:
1230                    # Create an IFrame object with the image as the content
1231                    if data_values:
1232                        popup_iframe = folium.IFrame(html=f"{self.encode_image(row['code'], df_rainfall)}", width=width//8, height=height//8)
1233                        folium.Marker([row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude']], popup=folium.Popup(popup_iframe),  
1234                                    tooltip=row['code'], icon=folium.Icon(color=color_markers[num])).add_to(my_map)
1235                    else:
1236                        folium.Marker([row['location.latitude'], row['location.longitude']], 
1237                                    tooltip=row['code'], icon=folium.Icon(color=color_markers[num])).add_to(my_map)
1238        
1239        # display the map
1240        return my_map

Creates a Folium map showing the locations of the weather stations in the given subsets.

Parameters:

  • subset_list : list of lists of str List of subsets of weather stations, where each subset is a list of station codes.
  • start_date : str, optional Start date in the format YYYY-MM-DD, default is None.
  • end_date : str, optional End date in the format YYYY-MM-DD, default is None.
  • data_values : bool, optional If True, the map markers will display a plot of rainfall data, default is False.
  • csv_file : str, optional The name of the CSV file containing the rainfall data, default is 'pr_clog_flags.csv'.
  • min_zoom : int, optional The minimum zoom level of the map, default is 8.
  • max_zoom : int, optional The maximum zoom level of the map, default is 11.
  • width : int, optional The width of the map in pixels, default is 850.
  • height : int, optional The height of the map in pixels, default is 850.
  • png_resolution : int, optional The resolution of the PNG image if data_values is True, default is 300.

Returns:

  • my_map : folium.folium.Map A Folium map object showing the locations of the weather stations in the given subsets.

1250    # transform the station status data
1251    def transform_station_status(self, station_status, today=datetime.date.today(), transformed_data=True):
1252        """
1253        Transforms the station status data into a dictionary with date as the key and online status as the value.
1254
1255        Parameters:
1256        ----------
1257        - station_status (DataFrame): The original DataFrame containing 'id' and 'online' columns.
1258        - today (datetime.date, optional): The date to be used as the index when the job is run. Default is the current date.
1259        - transformed_data (bool, optional): If True, the data will be transposed and formatted. If False, the original DataFrame will be used with an additional 'Date' column. Default is True.
1260
1261        Returns:
1262        -------
1263        - dict: A dictionary containing the transformed station status data.
1264            
1265        Note:
1266        -----
1267        - If transformed_data is True:
1268                The returned dictionary will have the date (today) as the key and the number of stations online for that day as the value.
1269                Example: {datetime.date(2023, 7, 29): {1: True, 2: False, 3: True}}
1270            
1271         - If transformed_data is False:
1272                The returned dictionary will have each row of the original DataFrame with an additional 'Date' column.
1273                Example: {0: {'id': 1, 'online': True, 'Date': datetime.date(2023, 7, 29)},
1274                        1: {'id': 2, 'online': False, 'Date': datetime.date(2023, 7, 29)},
1275                        2: {'id': 3, 'online': True, 'Date': datetime.date(2023, 7, 29)}}
1276        """
1277        # the time of the data to be in the index when the job is run
1278        # today = datetime.date.today()
1279        
1280        if transformed_data:
1281            # get the station status data
1282            status_transposed = station_status[['id', 'online']].T
1283            status_transposed.columns = status_transposed.loc['id']
1284
1285            # Drop the first row (which was the 'id' column) to make it a proper DataFrame
1286            status_transposed = status_transposed.drop('id')
1287
1288            # Convert the index to a datetime index
1289            status_transposed.index = pd.to_datetime([today])
1290
1291            # rename the index to date
1292            status_transposed.index.names = ['Date']
1293            return status_transposed.to_dict()
1294        else:
1295            station_status['Date'] = pd.to_datetime([today])
1296            return station_status.to_dict()

Transforms the station status data into a dictionary with date as the key and online status as the value.

Parameters:

  • station_status (DataFrame): The original DataFrame containing 'id' and 'online' columns.
  • today (datetime.date, optional): The date to be used as the index when the job is run. Default is the current date.
  • transformed_data (bool, optional): If True, the data will be transposed and formatted. If False, the original DataFrame will be used with an additional 'Date' column. Default is True.

Returns:

  • dict: A dictionary containing the transformed station status data.

Note:

  • If transformed_data is True: The returned dictionary will have the date (today) as the key and the number of stations online for that day as the value. Example: {datetime.date(2023, 7, 29): {1: True, 2: False, 3: True}}

    • If transformed_data is False: The returned dictionary will have each row of the original DataFrame with an additional 'Date' column. Example: {0: {'id': 1, 'online': True, 'Date': datetime.date(2023, 7, 29)}, 1: {'id': 2, 'online': False, 'Date': datetime.date(2023, 7, 29)}, 2: {'id': 3, 'online': True, 'Date': datetime.date(2023, 7, 29)}}
